references.text: An important application of Wavelet Transform is to assess or quantify the asynchronism of chest wall movements. This thoraco abdominal asynchrony (TAA) is a well known phenomenon in healthy infants during REM sleep but it is substantial in infants with obstructive airways disease. An inhibition of respiratory intercostal muscles during REM sleep causes a loss of ribcage stabilization and induces a paradoxical ribcage movement at the onset of inspiration. Generally the magnitude of RC/AB paradox is measured on Lissajous curves. The Wavelet Transform permits one to determine the simultaneous phase of ribcage and abdominal signals and can express at any time the degree of thoraco abdominal asynchrony
